titlePage.docImprint: Vol. Xxiv — no.44 Richmond, Va. Friday, February 20, 1863 price one Cent

div1.head:
Richmond Dispatch
by Cowardin & Hammersley.
div1.p:
the Daily Dispatch is served to subscribers at Six and A Quarter Cents Per week, payable to the Carrier weekly.
Price for mailing, $4 a year, or $2.50 for six months, in advance.
the Semi-Weekly Dispatch is issued every Tuesday and Friday at $2.00, in advance.
the Weekly Dispatch is issued every Friday, and mailed to subscribers at $1 per annum.
Advertisements published until forbid, will be charged 50 cents per square of eight lines for the first insertion, and 25 cents for each continuance

div3.head: Later from the North.
div3.p: We have received the New York World and Herald, of the 16th inst., and make the following summary of the news they contain:

div4.head: John Van-Buren's speech.
div4.p: D. A. Mahoney, who succeeds Boileau by appointment of the Democratic Central Club of Philadelphia, writes an article in the New York World, of the 14th, on John Van Buren's speech in which he says:

q.p:
"If he (V. B.) represents the Democracy in New York, there is a vast charm between them and the Democracy of the Northwest, who 'are for a vigorous prosecution of peace,' who believe the war is prosecuted for the purpose of perpetuating the existence of the Abolition Republican party, and as one means for the subjugation of the Southern States and people.
We of the Northwest are not in favor of such purposes.
We of the Northwest, especially those of Illinois, Indiana, and Iowa, are opposed to further prosecution of the existing war. Some of us never believed the object of the war was the restoration of the Union.
Why should that party become the special guardian of that compact, which is denounced as a covenant with death and a league with hell?
My object is to produce harmony between the conservative element of New York and the Northwest.--Does not Mr. Van Buren represent the conservative sentiment of New York in favor of a vigorous prosecution of the war for the purpose indicated by the emancipation proclamation, acts of confiscation, and concomitant acts of plunder, which have become characteristic of almost every Abolition and Republican office holder and contractor?"

div4.p:
The World, commenting on this article or communication of Mahoney, says: "The West is undergoing an entire revulsion of feeling, and it is the most alarming sign of the times." It thinks the West despairs of success of the Union arms, and has no heart-for the interminable war. The pressure of pecuniary interests has caused this powerful reaction.
If Abolition policy is successful, the resulting prostration of Southern industry would dry up the main source of Western prosperity.
The West "went in" for a short, vigorous, and successful war, which would permanently restore, not destroy, their best market.
After sacrificing the value of their crops for two years, and seeing less chance than ever of restoring the Union as it was, large masses of her people have become advocates of peace.
Feeling is vigorous and earnest, and is rapidly spreading over all that portion on the great rivers.
The World fears, if the Administration's policy is not speedily changed, the calamities of the next six months will be more serious and portentous than any the country has yet experienced.
The World has the following editorial remarks about Van Buren's speech:

q.p:
Let the emancipation proclamation, which is already a demonstrated failure, be revoked; let the door be kept open for a return of rebels by a standing offer of amnesty whenever they will submit to the Constitution; let men of capacity be put in the War and Navy Departments, and the great body of the Democratic party will cheerfully support the Administration until it can be constitutionally superseded by a new Presidential election; is it will put Banks in the War Department and restore McClellan to his position as General-in-Chief; discard the Abolition scheme and place the direction of the war in the most capable hands.
The doom of the Union is sealed unless the above policy is renounced; for, if there is anything absolutely certain, it is that the Democrats, who will cheerfully fight for the Union, will not support an Abolition war.

div4.head: Another speech from Vallandigham.
div4.p:
Vallandigham made a great speech in Newark, New Jersey, on the 14th, to an immense and enthusiastic crowd.
The peace resolutions of the Illinois Legislature were adopted as the expression of this meeting Mr. V. spoke of "the iniquitous despotism" of Lincoln's Administration, and said:

q.p:
I am here the representative of the peace sentiment of the Northwest.
[Great applause] There never was a time when in the hearts of the people there was not an undying opposition to the war. Seventy-five out of every hundred of the men of the Northwest are in favor of a cessation of hostilities and a commencement of the experiment of restoring the Union by constitutional and peaceful measures.
[Cheers.] I do not believe the South will accept terms from this Administration.
There is as much free speech south as there is North to-day.
[A voice, "A little more."] And there was a great deal more some time since than there was here. ["That's so." Cheers] The day has gone by when a war for the restoration of the Union can by any possibility be successful.
[Applause] If Mr. William H. Seward is in earnest, he either cannot control the Administration or he can. If he cannot, let him be honest enough to resign.
[Cheers.] If he can, let him give evidence of his sincerity by changing the policy of the Administration.
[Cheers.] There is a conservative party of which W. H. Seward is to be leader — the same who was the author of the phrase "irrepressible conflict; " the man who first signed his hand to the warrants for arbitrary arrests.
I want the Union as it was — part slave and part free.
I am ready to appeal to the people for their verdict upon this subject.
[Cheers] Will the war continue until the the 4th of March, 1865? ["Never, never." from all parts of the room] Will you send out your sons again to the battle-field?
[Overwhelming cries, "No, never! "] Shall they be conscripted to carry on this war for two years more and for the negro? ["No, never!"] Shall we do this with the vain, futile absurd, and most unfounded hope that after the 4th of March, 1865; after four years of such a war as God Almighty never permitted to scourge any land, you will go back again to a war for the Union? ["No, no,"] The people of America must choose now the alternative.
The term of a large portion of the army expires in May or June.

div4.p:
"I believe the people of the United States are satisfied that this is a miserable crusade against African slavery, with which you of New Jersey have no more to do than with polygamy in Turkey.
We have submitted as no people ought ever to have submitted for an hour — to the taking away of our rights not for a moment." We did so "on the pledge that in three months the rebellion would be crushed out. We never intended that we were to be crushed out ourselves"--[Laughter and applause.] He warned them not to "inaugurate a revolution in our own midst.--Do they not know that the men who begin revolutions, always perish by them?" If New York and New Jersey countenance this Administration in any further usurpations, the Northwest will not go with them.
[Loud cheers.] "Our day is coming; but if the trial is to be begun in some method unknown to the Constitution and laws, and it be reverted back to the old standard that might makes right, then know you that we have the might and the right too." [Great applause]--He concludes with a prayer that "God would bring this people through the Red Sea to the promised land of peace."

[I have given you the above specimen sentences from this speech, which looks something like a "lucid interval" in the Northern mind.
Their army will be 300,000 only in June.
Let us keep ours up to 500,000, and dictate peace at Washington or Alexandria.]

div4.head: From the army of the Potomac.
div4.p: The following extracts are taken from the New York World, of the 16th:

q.p:
General Hooker has issued a general order to the Army of the Potomac, in which it is announced that the order for the enlistment of volunteers in the regular service has been resoluded.
The sale of subsistence to citizens residing within the limits of the army, and its distribution to those who are destitute, is authorized upon the applicants taking the oath of allegiance, and swearing they are without other means of sustaining life.

div4.p: [Having, in defiance of all law, stolen private property, they offer a premium to promote per jury as the only means of escaping starvation.]

Captain B. C. Berry and A. M. Seymour, 2d regiment N. Y. cavalry, have been dishonorably dismissed from the U. S. service for desertion on the march to meet the enemy January 21st, 1863 [Has Hooker looked for them in the mud of Stafford Diligent excavation might exhume them.]
The costly furniture of the Phillips House, recently burned down, was saved and placed in the Lacy House, where such as in appropriate will be applied for hospital necessities.

The World, in an editorial, says: "An order has been issued prohibiting the circulation of all newspapers in the Army of the Potomac until further orders, " and proceeds to denounce the same.
It says the Administration hopes by this means to prevent a knowledge of the growing discontent from teaching the soldiers, for fear it would affect their morale. The newspapers did not produce the present state of feeling throughout the country and in the army.
The absence of newspapers will increase and embitter the feelings of the soldiers.

div4.head: From Washington.
div4.p: --The Senate took up the conscription bill Monday, and pressed it to a final vote.

Bills are prepared on emancipation appropriating ten millions of dollars for the violation of slavery in Maryland, and one and a half millions for Western Virginia, and four hundred and fifty thousand for Delaware for same purpose.

The McDowell Court has adjourned after sixty-seven days work.
The finding is not yet published.

Chase regards the uniform currency and Bank bill as absolutely essential to the successful working of the finances, and expects great aid from the consequent rise in value of United States bonds.--Should the banking bill fail, he does not think the loan bill can be worked out to successful results, but the issue of legal tender notes must then be increased indefinitely, which will result disastrously to public and private interests.

Carllale proposes that the President's proclamation, after the popular ratification of the act making West Virginia a State, shall not be issued until the counties of Boone, Logan, Wyoming, Mercer, McDowall, Pocahontas, Raleigh, Greenbrier, Monroe, Pendicton, Fayette, Nicholas, and Clay, (now under rebel control,) have been allowed a free and fair opportunity for voting upon such ratification.
The loyal Indians have taken a rebel flag and Albert Pike's manuscript treaties with Southern Indians, 100 horses, and $1,200 in Confederate money.
The Bank bill is likely to meet with opposition in the House on the ground of conflicting with the rights of States.
Gen. Shields has been ordered to the Department of the Pacific.
Gen. Phelps has been nominated for a Major-General of Dec., 4, '61, thus out ranking, Burnside, Hooker. &c.

The World, editorially, is in favor of the Administration accepting the proposition of Napoleon, and concludes its leading article thus: "It would seem, therefore, to be our single duty to prepare ourselves as rapidly and as calmly as becomes a great people, for the fresh complications which a foreign recognition of the Confederate States must inevitably introduce into the struggle we are sustaining."

Recent town elections, says the World, in New York, show immense Conservative gains over the vote of last fall.
We judge if an election for Governor were to take place next week, a Democrat would be chosen by 100,000 majority.
The Alabama was spoken on the 28th ult., thirty miles N. E. of St. John's.

div4.head: The Recent skirmish on the Peninsula.
div4.p: The Philadelphia Inquirer has the following correspondence relative to the late brush near Williamsburg:

div5.head:
Camp of the 5th Penn. Cavalry,
near Williamsburg.
Va.,
February 9th, 1863.
div5.p:
On the afternoon of the 7th instant, the 6th squadron of the 5th Pennsylvania cavalry was sent on a reconnaissance up the Richmond road, beyond Williamsburg, Va. When near Burnt Ordinary, they fell in with the rebel pickets, which the advanced guard charged, followed by the remainder of the squadron.
On arriving at a church near the above place, in a thick wood, they were suddenly opened upon by a murderous fire from infantry, concealed and protected by the dense underbrush.
At the moment of confusion, produced by the infantry fire, which emptied some fifteen or twenty saddles, the rebel cavalry charged down on the party with such impetuosity that our men were compelled to fall back or suffer both on flank and in front by the combined attack.
They formed and were again overpowered and out-numbered, so that no effectual stand could be made until Six mile Ordinary, a place a short distance in the rear, was reached, when the advancing foe was checked and forced to fall back.
The accidents on the occasion were the capture or killing of five commissioned officers.

Captain Anderson Faith, who commanded the force, was himself severely wounded, and Lieut. James Smith, of company A.
also a volunteer, and who was at one time entirely cut off, but escaped unhurt.
Thirty men are missing.
From what can be learned there were five men killed, fifteen wounded, and the remainder captured, while it is thought some of the officers were killed.
Considering the fact that the 5th Pennsylvania Cavalry are continually scouting, and twice or thrice a week going within and beyond the rebel lines, capturing and killing many of their men, it is not at all to be wondered at that they should once thus have been met. But even in this affair the traitors did not escape their share of punishment.
Many of them were seen to bite the dust, and their loss in killed, beyond doubt, exceeds ours.

div4.head: The Alabama —— her capture of the Hatteras — Ovation to Captain Semmes.
div4.p:
The arrival of the Alabama at Kingston, Jamaica, after her exploit in sinking the Hatteras, has been published.
The Florida is also there, and, as the Yankee papers report, "is watched by the U. States steamers R. R. Cuyler and Santiago de Cuba." The Kingston Standard, of the 25th ult., says:

q.p:
The Alabama is consigned to Messrs Charles Levy & Co., of this city, and is now receiving coal, &c., at Port Royal, from Messrs T. D. Pass & Co. She called into this port to receive casual repairs.
Capt. Semmes, we learn waited on His Excellency, the Lieutenant-Governor, in Spanish Town, yesterday.
Several of the Confederate officers were ashore in gray uniforms and we learn that the prisoners will be left in charge of the American Vice Consul here.

div4.p:
We understand that in the encounter the Alabama received some damage, and that several shipwrights and caulkers have been dispatched to Port Royal to repair the damages.
We gather the following additional particulars:

On Sunday, the 11th inst., at about 2½ o'clock, the Brooklyn, sloop of-war, 21 guns, Com. Rell, lying at Galveston, Texas, discovered a sail, which she supposed to be a merchantman running the blockade, and immediately signalized the Hatteras to give chase.
The Hatteras pursued her until dark.
The Alabama then hove to and awaited her approach.
The Hatteras was prepared, and all the men went to quarters.--She bespoke the stranger, who replied she was "Her Britannic Majesty's steamer Petrel." Capt. Blake, of the Hatteras, responded.--In the meantime the Alabama attempted to manœuvre to the stern of the Hatteras.
While off the port quarter Capt. Blake said he would send his boat on board, and while in the act of lowering the boat the Alabama sent a blank cartridge astern of the Hatteras.
She hailed her and said she need send no boat, as she was the Confederate steamer Alabama. Capt Blake then gave the order to fire, and the engagement ensued.
In about ten minutes a hole was discovered between wind and water in the Hatteras.
Fire also broke out in the fore peak in the lower deck, but was put out. A shot was sent through her steam-chest.
She then surrendered, being completely disabled.
The Alabama sent all her boats to take the crew off, and in a few minutes after this she sunk.
Only the ship papers were saved.

The Alabama made Port Royal in eleven days. A boat's crew from the Hatteras, seven in number, is missing, supposed to have gone back to Galveston.
Little personal injury was sustained on both sides.

Capt. Semmes had a reception at the Commercial Exchange, at Kingston, which was given to him by the merchants of that city.
He was lustily cheered.
The American Consul had chartered the ship Borrowing to bring the crew of the Hatteras to the United States.

div4.head: Religious Services in Baltimore — U. States orders Concerning them.
div4.p:
New Military Order.--Since the adjournment of the East Baltimore Methodist Episcopal Conference last March, a large number of that denomination have worshipped in the new Assembly Rooms on Sunday, where E. F. Busey, S. A. Wilson, and others, have preached.
Two large flags were left there over night, and were seen on Sunday.
Some members left the room.
The Provost Marshal hearing of it, ordered the superintendent of the room as follows:

q.p:
"I understand considerable disgust is excited in view of a class of persons who assembled at your rooms in consequence of the presence of the American flag.
You will hereafter cause constantly to be displayed, in a conspicuous position at the head of the hall, a large size American flag, until further orders.

div4.p: The congregation gives notice that no religious services will be held by them in future in the New Assembly Rooms, and as soon as a suitable place can be obtained due notice will be given.

div4.head: Cutting the Levees to get in rear of Vicksburg.
div4.p:
On the 2d inst. a Federal force, under Gen. German, commenced the work of cutting the levee of the Mississippi at the Yazoo Pass.
The water was expected to rush in on the 3d inst. A letter gives the following results expected from this operation:

q.p:
A navigable channel will thus be opened to the rear of Vicksburg, in a direction which is not fortified by the rebels, and I can see nothing to prevent our mosquito fleet from moving immediately in the Yazoo and taking possession of the rebel steamers that lie in the river.
Moreover, the formidable army threatening the rebels at Vicksburg from this direction must strike terror to their hearts and result in their final discomfiture and overthrow.
Gen. Grant, in the meanwhile, is not idle.
In the midst of obstacles apparently insurmountable, he is laboring on, controlling circumstances, and will in my opinion finally overcome all opposition and take possession of Vicksburg.
The mosquito gunboat Forrest Rose, the ram Lancaster, and two transports of troops, are now at the pass.

div4.head: The Yankee armies East and West.
div4.p:
The Philadelphia Inquirer, of the 16th inst, does not see any obstacle now to taking Richmond, as it learns that nearly all the Virginia army has gone to Vicksburg.
It has the following items about the Federal armies:

Every day brings us new proofs from General Hooker's command that he is proceeding rapidly, intelligent and successfully in the reorganization of the Army of the Potomac, the system of corps d arms has entirely superceded grand divisions, the headquarters of each corps being designated by a blue swallow-tailed flag with a white Maltese cross, and the number of the corps in red.

Rosscrans is hard at work, organizing, and sending out expeditions toward: Shelbyville and McMinnville.
His army is in excellent condition, but the roads are deep mud, the railroads are not thoroughly repaired, the turnpikes are cut up. When he moves it will be still further from his base, and he wants a stronger cavalry to guard his flanks.--Eager as we are for news of movement, necessary as it is to make the most of our time, we trust Rosscrans implicitly, and do not want him to move until he is ready, feeling assured that then he will move to victory.

div4.head: Later from Europe.
div4.p: --The Royal Mail Steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 31st ult., via Queenstown on the 1st inst., arrived at this port to-day.
The steamer New York arrived at Liverpool on the 25th, and the Nova Scotian on the 30th.
The Asia passed, on the 2d inst., a hundred miles west of Cape Clear, the steamer City of Baltimore.
It is stated that Heenan has matched for a prize fight with an unknown for $10,000.
The political news is unimportant.
It is reported that if Napoleon's proposal is rejected, France will recognize the South.
The emancipation demonstration at Exeter Hall was one of the most enthusiastic and imposing scenes that has been witnessed in London for a long time.

In numbers it was one of the most important since the days of the Corn Law League.
The hall was crammed and two other meetings were organized outside.
The resolutions reiterate the sentiments of the Emancipation Society, and express great sympathy for the North.

An amendment expressing sentiments hostile to the emancipation proclamation was promptly voted down, and the resolutions were carried almost unanimously.
The London Times was denounced by the speakers amidst groans and hisses similar to those given at similar meetings held at Bradford and other towns.

It is assumed by several writers that the proposals of mediation made by the Emperor is mere the preliminary to more important steps, and if refused, that the recognition of the Confederates will probably follow, whether England fevers the movement or not.

The operatives of Bradford have adopted a memorial, thanking America for the relief afforded them and suggesting that assistance be afforded to them to emigrate to the United States as the more effectual way of affording them relief.
The Times indulges in a most gloomy picture of the present crisis in America, both military and financial.

div4.head: The Emperor Napoleon's American proposals.
div4.p: The Paris correspondent of the London Times says:

q.p: A difficulty is reported between the British Government and the Washington Cabinet, on account of resent alleged seizures of English vessels off the Bahamas.

div4.p:
The Polish rebellion has not been by any means thoroughly subdued.
The insurgents triumphed near Piolskaw.
They were reinforced from the better classes from Warsaw, &c.

The cause of the insurrection in Poland was a conscription whose "main object was to rid the country of all individuals apt to disturb public tranquility." Recruits were taken exclusively from the students, the trades, and the manufacturing classes — the most intelligent part of the community.
They were seized at midnight, handcuffed and lodged in the citadel.
Awful enormities have been committed.

"An extensive anarchical conspiracy" has broken out in Greece, and a "Chinese Rebellion" is reported in the London News.
[The world generally seems to have gone deranged.
Satan has certainly been let loose.]

The Paris correspondent of the London Times says: "It is conjectured that the Emperor's proposals are meant as merely preliminary to a more important step on his part.
I should not be surprised to learn that in case of their formal rejection the Emperor would then consider whether the moment has not at last arrived for the recognition of the Confederacy, and this whether England joins him or not."

The London Times has a characteristically gloomy article on the prospects of the North, both in a financial and military sense, and as regards the latter, it says, "perhaps at no time during the war has fortune declared so decidedly against the North over the whole area of military operations."

"It is conjectured that the Emperor's proposals are meant as merely preliminary to a more important step on his part.
I should not be surprised to learn that, in case of their formal rejection, the Emperor would consider whether the moment has not at last arrived for the recognition of the Confederacy, and this whether England joins him or not."

The London Globe suggests the probability that the pacific proposals of the Emperor may be designed as laying ground for ulterior action in case of refusal by the Federal Government, the alternative being the recognition of the Southern Confederacy by France.
The Globe does not believe that the time has yet arrived for the Federal Government to enter upon pacific negotiations.
The London Express in an article on the Emperor's preposition, points out that no nation which has not had the means of communicating with any other nation, has obtained or even claimed recognition.

The London correspondent of the Manchester Guardian learns that the Emperor's proposal for a conference was sent out to Washington without previous communication of it to Mr. Slidell and that the proposition is considered by Mr. Slidell and other Southerners to be entirely inadmissible.
The same writer says he hears of a new difficulty between the British Government and Cabinet at Washington, in connection with recent alleged seizures of English vessels off the Bahamas, made within the proscribed nautical league of the British shore.
He also reiterates his statement as to the free negotiation of Confederate cotton warrants in London, and says these warrants were being largely used in the purchase of ships and stores for the Confederates.

div4.head: Sir Robert Peel on the American question.
div4.p:
Sir Robt. Peel had been speaking on the American question, and said that he was one who hoped, as an individual, to see the States ultimately become separated and independent of each other.
He condemned that odious and abominable proclamation of President Lincoln, which emancipated the slaves in the rebel States only, and said that if they followed the course of the battles which have taken place during this great conflict they might almost fancy that they saw the god of battles fighting for the South.
He should be glad to look back to 1863 and say that he belonged to a Government, headed by the most popular statesman that ever ruled the destinies of England, which by acknowledging the independence of the South led also to the emancipation of the slave.
--The Senate was called to order at 12 o'clock by Mr. Hunter, of Virginia.

The House joint resolution of thanks to Gen. Magruder, his officers and men, for gallant conduct at Galveston, Texas, passed February 16th, introduced in the Senate February 18th, and referred to the Committee on Military Affairs, was to-day reported in the Senate without amendment and passed unanimously.
The chairman of the Committee on Finance reported House bill to provide for refunding to the State of Alabama the amount overpaid by said State on account of the war tax of 1862, which was passed.

Mr. Hill, from the Military Committee reported a bill fixing the rank of those officers in the naval and military service of the Confederate States, holding commissions under the Provisional Government, when re-appointed officers of the same grade under the permanent Government.

Mr. Hill, from the Committee on the Judiciary, reported a bill to after and amend the act for sequestrating the estates, property, and effects of alien enemies, and for indemnifying citizens of the Confederate States and persons aiding the same, in the existing war, passed August 31, 1861, and an act altering and amending the same, approved February 15, 1862; which was read and put on the calendar.
The Senate then proceeded to the consideration of the unfinished business — the act exempting certain persons from the military service; which was amended and debased the hour of adjournment.

div4.head: House of Representatives.
div4.p: --House met at 12 o'clock, and was opened with prayer by Rev. Mr. Wise.

Mr. Miles, of S. C., from the Committee on Military Affairs, reported back the bill to exempt certain persons from military duty, and to repeal all acts heretofore passed by Congress on the same subject.
The bill was read first and second times and ordered to be printed, a motion to make it the special order for Saturday having failed.

Mr. Chilton, of Ala. reported back from the Committee on Quartermaster and Commissary Departments the bill to prevent frauds in the Quartermaster and Commissary Departments, and the obtaining, under false pretence, transportation for private property, and moved that the bill be taken up for consideration at once.
On this motion the ayes and noes were called, and resulted — ayes 57, noes 19--so the bill was taken up.
The bill was considered by the House and agreed to. The following is a copy as it passed the House:

list.item: Section 1. The Congress of the Confederate States of America do enact, That it shall not be lawful for any Quartermaster or Assistant Quartermaster, Commissary or Assistant Commissary, or the clerks, agents, or employees of said officers, while in the employ of the Confederate States, to buy, traffic, trade or speculate in, either directly or indirectly, for the purpose of making gain to themselves respectively, or any one or more of such persons, by a re-sale, any article of food or clothing, or material of which the arms is made, or which enters into and constitutes a part of the same or any article whatever, which is required to be purchased for the use of the army or the prosecution of the war by either of these departments, whether specifically named above or not, the object being entirely to prohibit these officers, their clerks, agents, and employees, from buying for the sake of gain by a resale any article which enters into and constitutes usually a part of either the quartermaster or commissary, military or medical stores of the Confederacy.

Sec. 2. Be it further enacted, That no person shall knowingly give or accept transportation of any commodity or property of any kind under the false pretence that such commodity or property belongs to the Government of the Confederate States, when in truth it belongs to private persons; nor shall any one purchase property of any kind under the false pretence that he is purchasing the same for the use of the Government of the Confederate States, when in truth the purchase is made in whole or in part on another and different account; nor shall any one in the service of the Government derive any profit to himself, or confer profit by collusion upon another, by selling, exchanging, or disposing of, any property belonging to the Government.

Sec. 3. Be it further enacted, That no one in the employment of the Government shall credit himself for any voluntary contribution in work, labor, materials, or of any property, whatever, that may be donated for the use of the Government or the soldiers in the army, whereby such person shall make any profit either directly or indirectly to himself.

Sec. 4. Be it further enacted. That it shall be the duty of the Government officers aforesaid, and each and every person in their employ, to take a correct receipt for all moneys paid out on account of the Government, setting forth truly to when paid, when the amount paid, and on what account the same was paid; and if such payment was made on account of property purchased for the Government such receipt shall truly set forth the name of the person from whom the same was purchased, and the place of his or her residence, the price agreed to be paid, and the subject matter of such purchase, and when such payment was made; and in accounting for the disbursement of public moneys no officer shall credit himself with moneys paid out which were not in good faith actually paid out.

Sec. 5. Be it further enacted, That if any Quartermaster or Assistant Quartermaster.; Commissary or Assistant Commissary, or an officer, employee or agent of any Quartermaster or Commissary, shall take a blank receipt for any article bought for the army, he shall, when convicted, be fined not less than $500, and shall be put into the ranks for the war, to serve as a private soldier.

Sec. 6. Be it further enacted, That any person in the employment or service of the Government as aforesaid, and all other persons coming within the purview of this act, who shall violate any of the provisions of the foregoing sections, shall be liable to indictment, and fined in a sum not less than one thousand dollars, and imprisoned not less than one year, nor longer than five years, to be imposed by the judge or jury trying the cause, according to the judicial proceedings in force in the several States: Provided, The provisions of this act shall in no wise interfere with or impair the civil remedy which the Government may have against any of said officers or their securities or employees for frauds, peculations, or misapplication of the moneys entrusted to them respectively by the Confederate States: Provided, also, That all conservators of the peace who, by the laws of the several States, have jurisdiction to commit or bind over offenders for breaches of the criminal laws of the State in which they may reside, shall have power to commit or bind over, in a sufficient recognizance, offenders against the provisions of this law to appear at the next term of the District Court of the Confederate States within the jurisdiction of which the offender was committed for trial, in the same manner and under the same rules as if such preliminary trial were had before the Judge of such District Court: and the Judges of the Confederate Courts having jurisdiction of the offences defined by this act shall, at the commencement of each session of their respective courts, give this act and its provisions specially in charge to the different grand juries.

div4.p:
Mr. Hilton, of Fla, from the Military Committee, reported a bill to be entitled an act in relation to substitutes in the army.
Placed on the calendar and ordered to be printed.

Mr. Hodge, of Ky., from the Committee on Naval Affairs, reported a substitute for the printed bill to reorganize the navy.
The bill was made a continuing special order.
On motion of Mr. Kenner, of La., the House then went into secret session.
Senate.--The Senate met at 12 M. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Moore.

Mr. Brannon, from the Committee for Courts of Justice, reported a bill authorizing the personal representative of John M. Alderson, dec'd, to deliver certain militia fees to the Sheriff of Greenbrier.

A message was received from the House of Delegates in relation to the duration of the present session of the Legislature.
Read and laid on the table.

Mr. Christian moved a reconsideration of the vote by which the bill increasing the salaries of certain officers of the Commonwealth was ordered to its engrossment.
He then moved an amendment, adding--"and the second assistant Clerk to the Secretary of the Commonwealth, one hundred dollars additional." The bill, so amended, was laid on the table and ordered to its engrossment.

The bill to impose liabilities on certain traitorous persons of the usurped Government in Western Virginia was taken up in order from the calendar, and drew forth considerable opposition from Senators on the ground of unconstitutionality, with an equally strong support on the score of inherent right, founded on State sovereignty.
The bill and pending amendments were laid on the table.

The "Act to legalize the records, proceedings, and acts of the County Court of Spotsylvania at the terms of the said Court held during the year 1862, at places in the said county other than the Court House;" was passed.
A number of bills were tabled, and others advanced to a second reading.
On motion, the Senate adjourned.

div4.head: House of Delegates.
div4.p: --The House met as 11 o'clock. Prayer by Rev. Dr. Deggett.

Senate resolutions calling on the Governor to demand of the President of the Confederate States the transfer to the civil authorities of Virginia of one C. J. A. Collins, arrested in the county of Prince George, Va, in July last, on a charge of kidnapping, and now confined in a military prison at Saulsbury, N. C., were read, and committed to the Committee on Confederate Relations.

Mr. Forbes, from the Committee on Courts, reported a bill charging the 39th section of chapter 184 of the Code, so as to allow compensation to the Clerks of Fluvanna and Albemarle County Courts for public services rendered by them.
Also, a bill changing the 6th section of chapter 200 of the Code, providing for the sale of free negroes.
Mr. Robertson, from the committee appointed for purpose, reported a bill (which was passed) incorporating the Richmond Importing and Exporting Company.

On motion of Mr. Prince the rules were suspended, and the bill authorizing fiduciaries to "invest funds in their hands in certain cares, and for other purposes," was taken up, and ordered to its engrossment.

On motion of Mr. Robertson, the resolutions offered by him a few days ago, looking to an increased production during the present year of certain agricultural commodities, [which were published at the time] was taken up.

Mr. Robertson was proceeding to elucidate the resolutions, when the hour of 12 having arrived, the Speaker announced the order of the day to be the general tax bill, which, without the unanimous consent of the House to the contrary, would be resumed.
Mr. Bradford moved to postpone the order of the day until 12½ o'clock, in order to allow the gentleman from Richmond to proceed, which was rejected--40 for and 41 against.
The consideration of the tax bill was then resumed, and during its pendency the House, at 1 o'clock, adjourned.

div3.head: Afraid of their own papers.
div3.p:
--A few days ago we conversed with some intelligent officers of the line captured from the Northwestern army.--They were from Illinois and Indiana.
They expressed great surprise and concern at learning something of the late proceedings of the Legislature and Conventions in those States.
To the question why they had not been posted by their own papers, from which we had received the news, they replied that they could get no papers for any price except an occasional rotten sheet that pandered to the Administration.
They were kept in utter ignorance of all the movements of the Democratic or Conservative party.
All papers which did not play the part of the spaniel to the tyrant at Washington were regarded as contraband, and excluded from the camps.
Whether this was done by order of the Government, or by the officers in command, they did not know; but certain it was they were effectually excluded, and had been since the capture of Corinth by Gen. Van Dorn. One gentleman told us that he had offered six dollars for a copy of the Chicago Times, and was unable to got it.

This virtual suppression of the Democratic or Conservative papers in the camps is done, no doubt, by Lincoln's pets of officers.
The Government itself would suppress them entirely if they dared to do so. But, knowing the indignation in which he is held by a majority of the people, Lincoln dares not molest the papers at home, but he has established a petty system of espionage which will exclude them from the camps, which policy enables him to hold on to his deluded soldiery a little while longer.-- Jackson Mississippian.

div3.head: Gen. Magruder.
div3.p:
--On the 11th inst, unusual honors were given to Gen. Magruder, at Houston, Texas.
The whole population turned out in procession, and after parading the streets stopped in front of a platform erected at the corner of Main and Congress streets, where a grand triumphal arch spanned the passage.
On the stage were 13 beautiful girls — each one representing a State of the Confederacy.
Here Dr. Wm. McCraven received the gallant General in a brief address.
The General responded.
Then a young lady (Miss Snyder) was led forth by Mr. James Sorley, formerly of Mobile.
The lady held in her hand a beautiful sword, crowned with a laurel wreath.
Mr. S., in behalf of the women of Texas, addressed the General in a long and eloquent speech.
At the close the sword was delivered to him, and he responded warmly.
A hymn was then sung; afterwards, great shaking of hands, and finally an adjournment to meet at a grand ball that was preparing for the night at Perkin's Hall.

div3.head: Fire.
div3.p:
--The alarm of fire about 11 o'clock on Wednesday night was caused by the burning of a tenement on Arch street, in rear of the Franklin Paper Mill, occupied as a blacksmith shop by S. R. Robinson.
The same place was burned out once before, when used by Burget & Boyle as a new factory.
The loss in the last burning was very small, probably not amounting to $100. The fire was no doubt the work of an incendiary.

div3.head: Dead.
div3.p: --One of the Southern Abolitionists captured by Gen. Floyd's army, in Kentucky, died a few days since at the Virginia Armory corner of Cary and 7th street's. His name was William Sturgeon, and he came from Johnson county, Ky. He was attached to company C, 29th regiment Kentucky troops, in the Lincoln service.

div3.head: Pardoned.
div3.p:
--John Edwards, private 1st regiment Virginia artillery, who was sentenced by Court- Martial to be shot for an alleged desertion, has been pardoned by Executive clemency.
Edwards was tried in December, was sentenced to be shot on the 31st of last January, but respited for twenty days by the President in order that he might collect evidence in his case.
The evidence was sufficient to warrant his pardon.

div3.head: At work.
div3.p:
--Wilson Damron, a Captain in the Lincoln army, captured by Floyd's army in Kentucky, who has been retained, with another Abolition officer, and put in the Penitentiary at hard labor, by order of Governor Letcher, by way of retaliation for the lawless incarceration of two Confederate officers in the Washington Penitentiary, is now a striker in the blacksmiths department of the State prison.
So far Lincoln has evinced no regret for the degradation of his minion, and made no effort to relieve him by sending home the two Virginians locked up at his instigation.

div3.head: New boats.
div3.p:
--The canal boat builders have availed themselves of the privilege granted them by Hon. G. W. Randolph, former Secretary of War, and have constructed a number of craft suitable for canal navigation.
The majority of those yet put on are intended solely for freight, and are open save at the two ends, one of which is enclosed for the use of the navigators, and the other housed in to protect the motive power of the boat, consisting generally of two stout males.
Several of the new boats made their appearance in the basin yesterday.

div3.head: Court proceedings.
div3.p: --Judge Wm. H. Lyons presiding.
Patrick McNemara was put on trial for robbing Lazarus Lawson, a soldier, out of $100. The jury found him guilty, and assessed his term of imprisonment at five years in the penitentiary.

James S. Tyler was tried for stealing a horse, worth $200, the property of Elizabeth Houpt. --Owing to defect in the indictment he was acquitted.
[Afterwards, the Grand Jury indicted the same party.]

Thomas T. Hall, a deserter from the Yankee army, who had taken the oath of allegiance to the Confederacy, was tried and convicted for stealing a set of buggy harness, the property of Edw. D. Eacho.
His sentence was two years in the State's prison.
Wm. A. Wright and Wm. M. Murray were fined $10 each for falling to attend the Court as witnesses for the Commonwealth vs. Wm. Reid and John T. Smith, charged with grand larceny.
In the case of James M. Elmore, tried on Wednesday for horse stealing, the jury sent the prisoner to the Penitentiary for two years.

The following parties were indicted by the Grand Jury, (John Purcell, foreman,) for felony, viz: John A. Whitman, for forging a one dollar Va. Treasury note; Jas S. Tyler, stealing a $200 horse from Elizabeth Houpt; Jas H. Sanders, stealing a $250 gold watch and other articles from Joseph F. Redford; Pat O'Donnell and Pat O. Neill, robbing John W. Burnett of one shawl after putting him in bodily fear; John W. Brown and Geo W. Hoppell, stealing $300 worth of wearing apparel from John H. Scribner; Albert W. St. Clair, stealing a $300 horse from Thomas Olburne; William Reid, stealing a coat from G. R. Howard; Joseph B. Goodman, stealing a pair of blankets from C. W. Spicer; John Ginotta, entering Dennis Maroney's house and stealing $75; Geo. Hoppell, Pat Cunningham, and other jail birds for assaulting and robbing Linneman Farrell; Geo Starkey and Jerry Devine, assaulting and cutting Warren S. Story with a dirk knife and robbing him of a watch; Ed Sullivan, Jerry Dunnavant, Mike Sullivan, Robt Lotsey, and Robt Clarke, assaulting and robbing Neal Ivey of money and a watch; Jno McKinley, stealing a barrel of whiskey from Joseph Brummell.

The indictment against Wm. Reid and John T. Smith for felony, in robbing Wm. M. Murray of a gold watch, was returned; a true bill against Reid, and ignored as to Frith.
The indictment against Wm. R. Warden, for obtaining two hogsheads of sugar from Richard Cauthorn, by false pretences, was ignored.

Mayor's Court, Thursday, Feb. 19th.--Jno. Moore, the man charged with attempting to rob and murder Simon Jacobs, at the Spotswood Hotel, was arraigned for examination, but the witness being in no condition to appear, from the nature of his wounds, the case was continued until the 27th inst.
Corbin, slave of D. R. Williams, was ordered fifteen lashes for selling in the Second Market- House without obtaining permission from the constituted authorities.
John Moore, the party charged with receiving fifteen gallons of whiskey, knowing the same to have been stolen from Mason & Harman, distillers, was examined and acquitted.
William Mackawitz, charged with being drunk and disorderly, and resisting the doorkeeper of the Theatre, was fined one dollar for getting drunk and let off.
Poitiaux, slave of Wm. Robinson, arrested for having no pass, and John W. Butcher, free negro, taken up for smoking a cigar in the street, were both discharged.
Supreme Court.--The following decisions were rendered by this Court in the 18th February, Judge Wm. Daniel presiding:

Insurance Company of the Valley of Virginia vs George Millison, late Sheriff of Hampshire, committee and administrator of George-Barley, dec'd, and E. Swatzweller, defendant — writ of supersedeas to judgment of the Circuit Court of Frederick county pronounced at the June term, 1859.
Ordered that said judgment be reversed and annulled.

Jones vs Bradshaw and others, upon appeal from a decision pronounced by the Circuit Court of Nottoway county, on the 1st of April, 1857, in a suit in which Bradshaw and others were plaintiffs, and Jones defendants.
Ordered that the decree in the lower court be reversed and annulled, and appellant recovers his costs, &c.
In the District Court of the Confederate States of America for the Eastern District of Virginia, February 18th, 1863:

Ordered That the Receivers, Thomas T. Giles, Henry L. Brooke, John T. Francis, Francis L. Smith, John M. Speed, Thomas H. Campbell, and William A Maury, do each of them, on the 20th day of March next, render before Wm. F. Watson, a Commissioner of this Court, an account of all matters in his hands, or under his control, as Receiver as aforesaid, appointed under the act of Congress entitled "An act for the sequestration of the estates, property and effects of alien enemies, and for the indemnity of citizens of the Confederate States, and persons aiding the same in the existing war with the United States, " approved August 30th, 1861; and to make and state an account and settlement, under oath, of his collection of moneys and disbursements under the act aforesaid: And it is further ordered that the Marshal of this Court cause to be published in the Richmond Enquirer.
Examiner, Dispatch, and Whig, for four weeks consecutively before said day of settlement, a copy of this order, and that the Clerk of this Court send a copy of one of said newspapers to the District Attorney of the Confederate States for this District.
A copy — Tests:

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of 86 acres of Land, in Henrico county, on the Deep Run Turnpike, at auction.
div3.p:
--As Administrator of John Ford dec'd, I shall proceed to sell, upon the premises, on Monday, 2d day of March, 1863, commencing at 11 o'clock A. M, the tract of Land on which the said John Ford resided, on the Deep Run Turnpike, in Henrico county, seven miles west of the city of Richmond, and adjoining the lands of Messrs R. J. A. Smith, John W. Alley, and James Shephard.
It contains 86 acres of land, well improved.
The improvements consist of a comfortable Dwelling, with several rooms; Barn, Stable, and other necessary out-houses, together with an excellent orchard of the choicest Fruit Trees.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
div3.closer:
John A. Hutcheson,
Late Sheriff of Henrico co, and as such Adm'r of John Ford, dec'd.
Sale by J. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
P. S.--The above will be sold at the risk and cost of Jas H. Ford who has failed to comply with the terms of sale. J. A. Hutcheson, Adm'r. fe 17

div3.head: Commissioner's Sale of lot and Dwelling-House in the city of Richmond.
div3.p: --As commissioner acting under a decree of the Circuit Court of the city of Richmond pronounced on the 7th day of February, 1863, in the case of Guardian, vs. Smith and others, I shall proceed to sell at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, beginning at 4 o'clock P. M., the property in said decree mentioned, consisting of a lot of ground, with a wooden dwelling-house and other improvements thereon footing 30 feet on the East line of 24 street, between Lee and M sts, running back 130 feet.

Terms.--One-fourth cash, balance at 6, 12 and 18 months, four negotiable acts, interest added, and title retained until all the money be paid and a conveyance directed by the Court, or the purchase, at his option, may pay the whole purchase money in cash.
The for 1863 to be paid by the purchaser.
div3.closer:
H. R. Women, Comm'r
Sale conducted by Williamsburg & Co, Aucts fe 17

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 24, Number 44, page 2.

div3.head: Remittances to the Dispatch.
div3.p:
--We have made arrangements with the Southern Express Company by which all money for subscripts, advertising, or job work, can be sent at our risk.
The money to be seat should be enclosed in an envelope, directed to the "Richmond Dispatch, Richmond, Virginia," and sealed with wax, writing the subscriber's name, post-office, and amount sent on the outside.
Deliver the same to any agents of the Southern Express Company, and take his receipt.
Send a letter to the office of the Dispatch by mail, advising us of the date when sent.
Our agents will observe carefully these directions, and fellow them.

div3.head: Type wanted.
div3.p:
--The proprietors of this paper wish to purchase 1,000 or 1,500 pounds of Nonpareil or Agate Typm.
The highest price will be paid.

div3.head: What does it Mean?
div3.p:
A committee in the Yankee Senate has made a report in favor of empowering Lincoln to call out the whole Yankee population!
What he wants with such a huge multitude, when, according to the report of his War Secretary, he has already 800,000 in the field, and when, according to Seward's magniloquent boast in his letter to Dayton, he has already nearly subdued the Confederacy, we are at a loss to imagine.
It cannot be that he wants them all for service in the South, in the half-conquered South, where, as his papers have been boasting for the last two years, the rebellion is on its last legs.
This were to give the lie to Seward, and to prove to the world that the rebellion, so far from being nearly extinguished, is more formidable than it ever was before.
What sort of half-conquest can that be which it requires 3,000,000 of fresh troops to completes?
Besides, we should suppose that Lincoln had found out before now that enormous numbers do not by any means ensure victory.
The history of Xerxes might have taught him as much; but assuming that the rapidly succeeding incidents of a bury life, which commenced in flat-boating and is now employed for the good of Yankeedom in governing that refined people, should not have allowed him leisure to dip into the recondite pages of Goldsmith and his Yankee imitators, his own experience might have answered the same purpose.
He has been trying to put down six or eight millions of rebels for two years, and has from first to last employed a million and a half of men in that service.
Yet the rebels are stronger today than they ever were before, and so far from being put down that they have beaten his troops in at least forty battles.
It can hardly be the rebels, then, that he calls out all these men to fight. --There must be an alarm in some other quarter.

In our opinion, Lincoln believes, or rather Seward believes, that the Emperor of the French means to take some step in this business.
He may be, or be may not be, right in his suspicion — our own opinion is, that he is not right; but it is evident to us that, right or wrong, such is his belief.
The silly vaporing of the New York Herald for a month or two past, and its constant reiteration of the same old tale about French intrigues, is not, we believe, one of those mare's nests which the Herald is always finding.
The writers have been prompted from Washington beyond all question. --In what form the Yankee Cabinet expect French interference — whether in that of a mere recognition, or of a treaty of alliance, offensive and defensive — It is obvious to us that this Senate report is a preparation for whatever may come.

For ourselves, we can say that we see no prospect whatever of French intervention, nor can we understand why Seward should be so much alarmed upon that head.
France has already obtained all she wants.
She has sent an army to Mexico, and will no doubt conquer that country.
She has blown the Monroe doctrine to the winds.
It will never be heard of again in our time.
It was, as interpreted of late years, ridiculous enough; but, as long as we were all one people, no European Power durst call it in question.
Now it has gone the way of all flesh, along with the old United States and the Constitution which created their Government.
The French want Mexico for its cotton-producing capabilities.
They will soon find that cotton cannot be produced by white labor and they will produce it by slave labor.
They can get the slaves nowhere else but in Africa, and to Africa they will report for them.
There is no Exeter Hall in Paris, and the Emperor Napoleon is no humanitarian.
If he want the negroes to cultivate his cotton lands he will not stand upon scruples.--He will open the African slave trade at once, and Seward will enjoy the enviable satisfaction of seeing the revival of that traffic; the result of his humane labors in endeavoring to destroy the States of this Confederacy.

div4.p: In Weldon, N C, on the 5th instant, by the Rev Mr. Bass, Mr. Chas Buker and Miss Augusta Kracke, both of Richmond.
On the morning of the 19th inst, at 4 o'clock, the daughter of Mrs. Mary Shoughrough, at the corner of 17th and Grace sts.

Her funeral will take place at 2 o'clock this evening.
The friends and acquaintances are invited to attend. *
At Louisiana Court-House, on February 18th, of typhoid fever, Sarah Douglass, eldest child of A C and S E Dean, aged 2 years 11 months and 7 days
The friends and acquaintances of the family are respectfully invited to attend her funeral this morning at 10 o'clock, from the residence of Mr. John T Salles, corner of Clay and Gilmer sts. *
Yesterday morning, Mary Ann, aged 1 year and 8 months, infant daughter of Mrs. Mary Ann Sugarow
Her funeral will take place from the residence of her mother, corner of 17th and Grace streets, this afternoon at half past 2 o'clock. Friends are invited to attend. *
on the 12th of February, James Herbert, only child of James P and Lucy G Figg, aged 8 days.

lg.l: Weep not for me, my parents dear,
I have gone to rest, you need not fear;
My stay was short, as you may see,

div4.p: Charlottesville papers please copy. *
In this city, on Wednesday, the 18th inst., Wm M, son of Jas D and Margaret P Scott, in the 10th year of his age. *

div4.head: Death of Capt. John W. Bullock.
div4.p:
Another brave and noble spirit has gone.
Another martyr to our holy cause — another only child of fond and loving parents — has fallen a noble sacrifice in his beloved country's cause.
He possessed those noble and beautiful traits of character which were most appreciated and admired by those who knew him best.
His high and stern sense of honor, his quiet and gentle disposition, and his energetic and thoughtful mind, were only equalled by his generosity and fidelity as a friend.
As a soldier, the following orders will speak for themselves: A Friend.

div5.head:
[Copy.]
Headqr's Cav. Div.
Army N. Y.
January 26th, 1863.
div5.p: It is my painful duty to announce to the Division the irreparable loss it has sustained in the death of Capt. John W Bullock, 5th Va. Cavalry.
He was wounded at Dumfries on the 27th ult., too severely for removal; but, though left in careful hands he yielded to the inevitable doom.

His bright eagle eye and clear ringing voice were ever conspicuous in fight, where he combined the impetuosity of youth with the coolness of a veteran and with all those heroic virtues which adorn the soldier and immortalize the patriot.
His company, to a man, devoted to their dashing young leader in mourning his early fall, must emulate the noble example which still lives a precious heritage to all who know him.

div5.head:
[copy]
Headq'rs Lee's Cav. Brigade,
January 28th, 1863.
div5.p: The General commanding the Brigade calls the attention of the officers and men of his command to the accompanying General Order, No. 1, Division Headquarters.
A scout penetrating the enemy's lines in the vicinity of Dumfries, reports Capt John W Bullock, 5th Va Cav, to have died from the effects of his severe wounds one week after he had received them.
Bullock needs no eulogy from me. He was known to all. With few, very few, equals, he had no superior in the cavalry service.
Such a man, dying in such a cause, deserves eternal glory in life everlasting.
May his brave sharpshooters soon have an opportunity to avenge him.

div5.head:
[copy].
Headquarters 5th Va. Cavalry,
January 27, 1863.
div5.p: It is with profound regret that the Colonel commanding announces to this regiment the death of Capt J W Bullock, who fall mortally wounded whilst gallantly leading his men against a greatly superior force of the enemy at Dumfries, on the 26th ult, and died the week following.

The gallantry and bravery of Capt Bullock as a soldier were only equalled by his generosity and faithfulness as a friend.
All who knew him loved or admired him for his talents and his virtues, and long will his memory live in the hearts of his comrades and friends, who so often witnessed his bravery and sagacity during the many days of peril through which he so gallantly led them.
And now, as our tears are Freely falling on his fresh grave, our souls are in arms to avenge his death.

div4.head: Resolutions of Condolence.
div4.p:
At a meeting of Company B, (Baylor's Light Horse,) 12th regiment Virginia cavalry, held at camp, near Mount Jackson, Lieut Geo. W. Roland was called to the chair, and Henry D Beall appointed Secretary.
The object of the meeting being to take action in regard to the death of private Resin Davis Hewitt, the following resolutions were unanimously adopted:

Whereas, This company has heard with profound regret of the death of their follow-member Resin Davis Hewitt, of Maryland, in a skirmish with the Federal cavalry, near Millwood, on Friday night, the 6th instant: Therefore,

Resolved, That in the death of private Hewitt not only this company, but this brigade and the Confederacy, has lost a soldier "without fear and without reproach," who, in all the trials of a soldier's life, both during his service in the Stonewall brigade and his subsequent connection with this company, reflected honor upon his native Maryland and the cause for which he so earnestly and unselfishly fought.

Resolved, That we tender his parents and friends our heartfelt sympathy in their bereavement — assuring them that no braver heart or more chivalrous spirit has been sacrificed on the altar of Southern independence during this war, and that, still cherishing his memory, we will emulate his quiet virtues, and, as far as in our power lies, avenge his death.
Resolved. That the Richmond Dispatch and Maryland Gazette be requested to publish the proceedings of this meeting.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--25 able-bodied negro men, accustomed to the use of the axe, for the balance of the year, to be employed in Albemarle county.
Apply to
div3.closer:
O Crew & Son,
17th street Richmond, or
S Kannesrly, Ja,
Hermitage, Augusta co, Va. fe 20--eod1w&sw2cw2w*

div3.head: Wanted — Rooms
div3.p:
--Wanted, one or two Rooms, furnished or unfurnished, with the use of a kitchen, to be paid for monthly in advance, if desired.
Address "Box 28?" City Post-Office, or "Captain," at this office.
References exchanged.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Fifty men for Provost Marshal's Guard at Lynchburg.
For particulars apply to
div3.closer:
D M Novell,
Southwest cor 14th and Main sts, or
J A Cahill,
Pro. Mar. Office, Lynchburg. fe 20--1t*

div3.head: Wanted — a situation
div3.p: --By a young man, in any active business; writes a good hand, and is willing to give his entire attention to his employer's business, and is a non conscript.--Address "Box 349," Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A young gentleman having obtained a furlough on account of his health, is desirous of obtaining a situation as Salesman in some store until April next.
Call to-day from 10 to 2 o'clock, room No. 31, Columbian Hotel.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--A situation as Bookkeeper or Salesman in some commercial house in the city.
Employment, and not salary, the object desired.
Address "J I V E," at this office.

div3.head: Wanted to hire.
div3.p:
--By the month, a Servant Girl, white or colored.
To one that will suit a good price will be paid.
Inquire of N W Nelson, 135 Broad street.

div3.head: Wanted to Rent.
div3.p:
--Two well furnished Chambers and Parlor, or one Chamber and Parlor, without Board.
First floor preferred.
Address "X Y Z." Dispatch office.

div3.head: Wanted to hire
div3.p:
--A White Girl or Woman (Irish preferred) to act as Nurse, to go to the country with a lady and two children.
Apply immediately to
div3.closer:
Dr. Henry,
Corner Grace and Henry sts. fe 20--1t*

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
--To hire two or three good Carpenters, to whom good wages will be paid.
Apply at the

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--An elderly man or Boy, to take charge of the Billiard room at the Spotswood Hotel.
Must come well recommended.
To a reliable party, a liberal salary will be paid.
Apply at the office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A situation by a young man who is exempt from military duty.
He writes a fair hand, and has some acquaintance with bookkeeping.
References given as to character and business qualifications.
Address "Box 663," Richmond, Va.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--A lady and gentleman having their own furniture, desire to obtain Board in some private family or boarding house in the city.
Address "Box 108," Post Office.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--An Overseer, to take charge of an estate 100 miles above Richmond.--Satisfactory references will be required.
A single man preferred.
A liberal salary will be given. --Also, a good boat Builder.
Address "Box 816," Richmond Post Office.

A man, 7 years of age of good complexion, and who can give good recommendations, would enter the service as a Substitute, either in infantry or cavalry.
Call at the Oyster Saloon on Main street, between 23d and 24th.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--To go in a good infantry company, for the war. For a sound man, over 45 a good price will be given.
Apply to Thos J. Hancock, at the Government stables on 18th street, between Franklin and Grace, West side.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid to a sound and reliable man, to go as a Substitute in a company making up at Camp Lea.
Apply at the new Tobacco Store, corner of 9th and Broad streets.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--To go in the 15th Virginia regiment.
For a man over 45 years of age a liberal price will be paid.
Apply on 4th st, between Jackson and Duval, to

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--The highest cash price paid for a Substitute of good character, to serve in one of the finest companies in the service.
Apply to

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--An able bodied man, well recommended, for which a liberal price will be paid.
For further information apply at the Linwood House, room No. 10, between the hours of 9 and 1 o'clock.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p: --Over 45 years of age. The highest cash price will be paid.--Call at Minnie & Co's, Main st, between 10 and 12 o'clock. Feb. 20

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--A Marylander, to go in a Maryland battery.
Address "T A M," Manchester, Va, stating where an interview can be had.

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--Over 45 and well recommended.
Apply at room No. 16, Columbian Hotel, between 9 and 11 o'clock, this day.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--Apply at Harvey.
Hunt, James & Co's, on Virginia street, under the Tobacco Exchange, from 9 o'clock until 12.

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid.
Apply to

div3.head: Substitute wanted.
div3.p:
--A liberal price will be paid to a sound and reliable man to go as a Substitute in a No. 1 company.
Inquire at Mrs. Barnes's, on Grace street, second door above St. Paul's Church

div3.head: Wanted — a Bugler.
div3.p:
--$2,000 will be paid for a Bugler, to go as a Substitute in a first rate Artillery company, stationed near Dublin Depot, on the Va and Tennessee Railroad.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Hughes, Cald well --Co,
No. 9 Pearl st. fe 18--3t*

div3.head: Substitute wanted
div3.p:
--For the balance of the war. For one over forty-five years of age, with reliable testimonials, a liberal price will be paid.
Apply at the store No. 9 Fourteenth st, between Main and Cary.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--A Girl, and a small Boy who I will put out for his victuals and clothes to a good home.
Inquire at my house, on 29th, near M street, Church Hill.

div3.head: For hire
div3.p: --A good washer and general house servant Woman.
div3.closer:
Bo A Grinnan,
Southwest cor Main and Adams sts. fe 20--2t*

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--I have two able-bodied negro men for hire, by the month.
They are good woodcutters.
div3.closer:
Wm Winston Jones,
Clay, bet 8th and 9th sts. fe 19--2t*

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--A good Cook, Washer and Ironer.
Also, a Dining-Room Servant, and a steady man, accustomed to working in a factory or in the field.
div3.closer:
Mrs. J Q James.
Corner 3d and Franklin sts. fe 19--6t*

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--I have for hire one superior Servant.
She is a good Cook, Washer and Ironer.
She can be found on Charity street, Duval's addition.
Apply to

div3.head: For hire.
div3.p:
--I have an accomplished Cook, Washer and Ironer, with three children, who I will hire to a good home for food and clothing.
Apply to
div3.closer:
Mrs. Ross,
On Franklin, bet 6th and 7th sts. fe 14--eod3t*

div3.head: For hire
div3.p:
--A Woman, of excellent character, as Cook in a private family.
She is without encumbrance.
Also, a Girl, for Dining-room Servant or Nurse, who is honest and can be recommended in every respect.
Call on Grace st, two doors above Adams.

div3.head: One hundred dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Ranaway from the subscriber, last spring, Albert, about 16 years of age, very black, open countenance, and limps when speaking.
He is supposed to be employed by some officer in General Lee's army.
I will give the above reward for his arrest and return to me, or confinement in jail so that I can get him.
div3.closer:
Jno D Quarles,
Corner Main and Foushee sts. fe 20--eod6t*

div3.head: Fifty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--I will pay $50 for the arrest and lodgment in a safe jail of my man George, if taken out of the city of Richmond or county of Chesterfield, or $20 reward if taken in those limits.
He left my house, in Manchester, on Saturday last, about 12½ o'clock P. M. He is about 6 feet high 23 years old, brown color, and weights about 130 pounds. He had on when he left a brown frock coat, and was well dressed generally.
He carried a bag of clothes with him. He came from near Danville, and is probably trying to get back.
He may hire himself to work in some camp, or try to get off on the canal.
He had on a good black hat.

div3.head: Ran away
div3.p:
--From the undersigned, about ten days since, my negro boy George.
For his apprehension and delivery to Mr. Robert Lumpkin a reward of $25 will be paid.
George is about 17 or 18 years old of a dark brown color, tolerably stout built, small head and face, walks slowly and freely; when spoken to replies slowly with a downcast look; had on when he left dark clothes, much worn, and an old straw hat; usually wears a short, shaggy, black overcoat.
He lived the latter part of last year at Mr. H J Smith's, near Fairfield, and was again hired there this year but ran off. He is probably secreted by some one in the city

div3.head: Five hundred dollars reward.
div3.p: --Deserted from comply E, 26th Virginia reg't, on the 1st inst, Henry Scott, an Irishman, about 47 years old, about 5 feet 6½ inches high; dark-brown or black hair; bluish eyes; dark complexion; has a ship tattooed on his breast, a woman on each arm, the woman on the left arm has a child in her arms; has a star on the back of the left hand, and has lost a portion of the middle finger of the right hand.--Henry Scott was mustered as a substitute for Robt Edmund son, of Halifax co, Va. The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me at the camp of the 26th Virginia regiment, Wise's brigade, near Chaffin's Bluff.
div3.closer:
John T Perrin, Capt Co B,
26th Virginia regiment. fe 20--11t*

div3.head:
Hdq'rs Mallory Troop,
Richmond, February 20th, 1863.
div3.p:
A few more Recruits are wanted to fill up my company of Cavalry, to serve as Gen. Lee's Body Guard.
Horses, equipment, a complete outfit, and $50 bounty, furnished to each recruit. --Those wishing to join this corps will report to me at Mr. Thos T. Johnson's office, opposite Columbian Hotel, or to Lieut David Johnson, at Camp Lee, by the 5th of March as no recruits will be received after that time.

div3.head: Deserted
div3.p:
--On or about the 20th of June last, John Foresee, a member of Comp'y F, 18th Georgia reg't. He was enlisted at Richmond on the 12th of October, 1861; has dark eyes; black hair; is about 5 feet 11 inches high, and is supposed to be in Powhatan county.
A reward of $30 will be paid for his arrest, and delivery to some proper officer.
div3.closer:
John F Hardin, Lt com'g Co F,
18th Georgia regiment. fe 19--4t*

div3.head:
Camp of Infirmary corps,
near King William Court House, Va, February 18th 1863.
div3.p: All absentees of this corps will report to me I shall address them as

div3.head: Beautiful improved farm, near Charlottesville, and Twelve or fifteen Negroes, for Sale.
div3.p: --In obedience to a decree of the Circuit Court of Albemarle, pronounced in the chancery suit of "Henderson and wife vs Crawford and als," the undersigned Commissioners will offer for sale, at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 3d day of March, 1863, (or the next fair day,) a beautiful estate, known as Meadow Creek, containing about 600 acres. This farm lies within a mile of Charlottesville, and less than a mile from the University of Virginia; has an excellent dwelling-house, and all the necessary out-house, and a fine peach orchard on the place.
It is seldom that so desirable a place, in the immediate vicinity of a large town, is offered for sale.
Will be sold at the same time and place, 12 or 15 likely Negroes, Household and Kitchen Furniture, a fine Piano, two good Mitch Cows, &c.
Terms--Pretty much at the option of the purchaser.
